stem: A traction injury affecting the C5–C6 roots produces weakness of shoulder abduction and external rotation with lateral arm sensory changes. Which peripheral nerves are most implicated?

choices.E: Posterior cutaneous nerve of arm and intercostobrachial

rationale_correct: Superior plexus (C5–C6) lesions commonly involve axillary, suprascapular, and musculocutaneous territories.

rationale_distractors.A: These are lower trunk/medial cord distributions (C8–T1 biased).
rationale_distractors.C: AIN/PIN are distal branch syndromes, not root‑level plexus lesions.
rationale_distractors.D: Long thoracic and spinal accessory produce scapular winging and trapezius weakness but are not classic for C5–C6 traction.
rationale_distractors.E: Cutaneous nerves listed don't explain the motor pattern.

evidence.citation: Selski D. Nerve Injuries of the Upper Limb (Slides). 2022.
